name: Christian Kabbalist Network
description: The Christian Kabbalist Network (c. 1490–1560) represents a pivotal intellectual movement that synthesized Jewish mystical traditions with Christian theology and Renaissance Neoplatonism. Building on the Florentine synthesis pioneered by Pico della Mirandola and Marsilio Ficino, this network carried Kabbalistic ideas northward into German lands and throughout Europe. Key figures like Johannes Reuchlin defended Hebrew learning against scholastic opposition, while systematizers like Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa integrated Kabbalah into broader frameworks of Renaissance magic and natural philosophy. The network connected scholars across confessional boundaries—Catholic friars, Protestant humanists, and independent occultists—united by their conviction that ancient Hebrew wisdom held keys to universal religious truth and the secrets of creation.
